comments.body:
I'm to integrate your changes and do some test.  After going through your code changes roughly,  I have a few questions:

<1> How is [meta_init_db()](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-sairedis/blob/94086867a93b21881387df1f2ba2d3763dc8796f/syncd/syncd.cpp#L3474)  used in the case of  syncd docker warm restart?

Is it an obsoleted function call or still playing some role?  

<2> How are flexCounter and flexCounterGroup recovered?
It looks we need to read the setting from the plain tables in FLEX_COUNTER_DB?
 
<3>For system restart, now we reach at the stage of data recovery, should we make sure all data in producer queue has been consumed before syncd shutdown as discussed in the thread for warm-reboot script https://github.com/Azure/sonic-utilities/pull/338#discussion_r223918235 ?

What if the lag member had been removed temporarily?   Due to port state down or some configuration state.
https://github.com/Azure/sonic-swss/blob/master/orchagent/portsorch.cpp#L2087
if lag was removed and there is no match for it we still try to match at random
Does it mean once the member port for each lag comes back, they may be put into the wrong lag?
Builds failed due to outdated schema. Dependency on sonic-swss-common.
retest this please
test this please

Jipang,

I could be wrong. But I am not sure we need to do that. My understanding is that SAI will initiate the save and syncd will simply discard all in-memory states. Because syncd is quitting after all.

I am not sure if you were asking about timing, I think remove_switch blocks until the SAI data has been saved to file system. So when we return from remove_switch(), we are ready to quit.

Let's talk tomorrow to sort this out. You might be talking about something I totally missed.

Cheers,
Ying

Ying,

Sorry I didn't put it clear enough.  I was thinking about the ConsumerTable pops implementation:
https://github.com/Azure/sonic-swss-common/blob/master/common/consumer_table_pops.lua#L61
Before storing the data to m_buffer of ConsumerTable, the same data has been saved to ASIC DB.  I assume the data in ASICDB will be used to during syncd warm start.

syncd uses ConsumerTable for processing request from orchagent and other processes.  If m_buffer happens to have unprocessed data the moment syncd breaks from the while loop upon 
SYNCD_RESTART_TYPE_WARM shutdown request, there could be data inconsistency between ASIC DB and ASIC.

After previous post,  I realized that this PR https://github.com/Azure/sonic-sairedis/pull/335 should have eliminated the problem with asicState.  Not sure about the cases for flexCounter and flexCounterGroup,  they use ConsumerTable too.

I might have missed some internal processing of select() which possibly makes that a non-issue.

Thanks,
Jipan

Jipan,

All that you said is very valuable. I am still learning syncd warm shutdown and restore expectations from SAI. The things you listed would be things that I need to validate once I have basic warm restore procedure sorted out.
The current change is a good starting point.  I think you may make further change later as needed with syncd restore processing.
I got verbal approval from Jipan and Kamil for this PR. I'll close the revert PR.

@kcudnik This is part of routing performance optimization. We want to handle as many events as possible already in the consumer buffer in one process function instead of waiting the while loop for each event. This was discussed about one month ago in the 4 way meeting. In this way, the performance improved ~200-300 routes per second.

comments.body: It seems that you are counting the time of running thread and decrease this amount time from sleep. This might not work if the running time exceeds the polling interval occasionally. Can we also handle this case, eg. plus additional sleep time when it's negative?

Sleep time is decreased by delay % poll_interval. And the actual time that it took to read counters + delay is passed to plugin to do the calculations.

For instance, if delay for reading counters was 120 ms, and the poll interval is 100 ms, and the previous delay was 40 ms, we pass to plugin a value (100 - 40 + 120) ms and sleep for (100 - 20) ms.
depends on https://github.com/Azure/sonic-swss-common/pull/179
retest this please

Can you provide more rationale for your split. what I understand from your code, is you move counterTable.set functions out of collectCounters(). when the thread is not collecting pfc watch counters, you split the counterTable.set into three parts (portstat, queuestat, and queue attributes).

What I do not understand why you choose this approach versus others. For example, in collectCounters, you can only collect one port, and then lock. That is another way to break a single lock into multiple small locks.

Sorry about deleting @marian-pritsak 's comment about "collectCounters requires lock"

Agree
@marian-pritsak Can you help to review?

I agree that when new oid is registered between 3 and 6, there is no counter available when plugin runs and we miss one round of result. That should be fine as in next poll interval we will have the information.
Even we have a giant lock to make collectCounter+runplugin atomic, we will still miss a round of result if syncd wants to add the new oid within the time period but wait for lock.

Im not sure if this is the right solution, since between step 8 and 9 state of oid can change, and you can get errors while getting counters, if all those oids are ports then maybe we can get away with this since port oids dont change, but for orther objects states can change and oid numbers can change
Nothing after step 5 is using SAI API, and if any OIDs changed, orchagent should know about it. So I would argue that we are safe here.

The oids are port oids and queue oids. I think queue oids also don't change. They seems to be read-only, and only depend on port and queue index from my understanding. In orchagent, we also only get the port and queue oids once when initializing the ports at the beginning and assume they won't change.
